dt: {bc}to follow the commands or guidance of

dt.t: Falling objects {wi}obey{/wi} the laws of physics.

et: Middle English {it}obeien,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}obeir,{/it} going back to Latin {it}oboedīre,{/it} from {it}ob-{/it} "toward, in the direction of" + {it}-oedīre,{/it} probably unstressed form (with {it}-oe-{/it} of uncertain origin) of {it}audīre{/it} "to hear" {ma}{mat|ob-|}, {mat|audible:1|}{/ma}

The {it}-oe-{/it} in {it}oboedīre{/it} is peculiar both because it is not the expected result of {it}-au-{/it} in a non-initial syllable (the regular outcome is {it}-ū-{/it}) and because -oe- is in any case rare non-initially. Various attempts have been made to account for the irregularity. Reflecting earlier suggestions, Michiel de Vaan hypothesizes pre-Latin {it}*ób-awizdijō{/it} > {it}*obowizdijō{/it} > {it}*oboizdijō{/it} (rounding of {it}a{/it} before {it}w,{/it} which is then lost, prior to the weakening of {it}a{/it} to {it}u{/it}) > {it}oboediō{/it} (with {it}z{/it} blocking monophthongization of {it}-oi-{/it} to {it}-ū-{/it} before succumbing to cluster reduction) (see {it}Etymological Dictionary of Latin and the Other Italic Languages,{/it} Brill, 2008). As an alternative to assumptions of questionable phonetic change, it has also been suggested that a base other than {it}audīre{/it} is at issue (Michael Weiss suggests {it}*ob-bhoi̯diō,{/it} from a nominal derivative of the base of {it}fīdere{/it} "to trust" [see {et_link|faith:1|faith:1}]; see {it}Outline of the Historical and Comparative Grammar of Latin,{/it} Ann Arbor, 2009, p. 120).
shortdef: to follow the commands or guidance of
to conform to or comply with
